items: By following the WHO protocol and taking the correct measures, Vale makes a relevant contribution to fighting COVID-19, including in the cities where it is present, which has become a priority due to two pillars in our strategy: Safety and Operational Excellence and a New Pact with Society.

To face the challenges brought by the COVID-19 pandemic, with responsibility, discipline, and a sense of urgency, a crisis response plan was established, with processes and actions that prioritize the health and safety of employees and communities in the territories where the company operates.

The internal procedure determines how the company's efforts should be based on mitigating the transmission of COVID-19 in its operations and, by extension, in the local communities of its operations, and its key objectives are: to protect the health of employees – own and third parties and communities; prevent SARS-CoV-2 infection at Vale's units worldwide; and guaranteeing safe operational continuity: providing the necessary conditions so that a minimum workforce can ensure safe production.

Employees must monitor their symptoms daily through the Checklist, and where the legislation allows, the daily questionnaire specific to each location must be completed by employees and third parties before their work shift and during days off.

Vale also decided to test all its employees as the third line of defense in the fight against the pandemic, creating yet another barrier to increase the security of operations and gain agility in the management of quarantine cycles.
Vale encourages each unit to assess its employees' risk and be proactive in implementing any measure of physical distancing considered a relevant mitigation strategy.
Since 2Q20, Vale has donated more than R$600 million to the fight against COVID-19 in the regions where it operates.
Since the pandemic's beginning, Vale has made itself available to the federal government, states, and municipalities to collaborate where necessary.
In March 2021, Vale hired Einstein to carry out technical consultancy in health management for Itabira through the Municipal Health Department.

Vale supported an epidemiological study on the prevalence of infection by the new Coronavirus and its evolution in the city, with the donation of 10,000 kits rapid tests and Personal Protective Equipment (PPE).

In 2020 we supported several non-partisan coalitions and campaigns to encourage Americans to register to vote and cast a ballot.
These groups include the Time to Vote Initiative, GaVoting Works, Business for America (BFA)’s Operation Vote Safe, and Civic Alliance.
We also made Election Day 2020 a paid holiday for our US employees to ensure they had ample time to exercise their right to vote and participate in America’s democratic process.
The Coca-Cola Company also fully respects the right of people to protest peacefully.

We publicly expressed our views on the Georgia voting legislation, and were actively engaged with the business community to share our perspectives on the legislation, both before it passed as well as engaging in conversations following passage.

Enfin, notre engagement en faveur du développement durable est lui aussi un engagement de longue date puisqu’en 2003, nous avons co-créé, avec l’ONG Rainforest Alliance, notre programme AAA pour une Qualité Durable, tourné vers la préservation de la nature et le bien-être des caféiculteurs.
Nous poursuivons nos programmes d’agroforesterie et avons déjà planté 5,2 millions d’arbres entre 2014 et 2020.
Tous les engagements de Nespresso sont disponibles sur https://www.nespresso.com/agit/
Enfin, nous tenons à préciser que dès la publication de ce rapport, nous avons proposé au CCFD de les rencontrer et de dialoguer avec eux. A ce jour, nous n’avons obtenu aucune réponse de leur part.

items: Enfin, l’ensemble des projets NBS de TotalEnergies suivent des cycles longs et seront suivis dans le temps : l’entreprise entend signer des contrats de longue durée avec ses partenaires afin d’assurer le suivi et la pérennité des activités.

Le projet NBS en République du Congo, porté par TotalEnergies et l’entreprise Forêt Ressources Management, fait l’objet d’études d’impact environnemental et sociétal, y compris des consultations avec les représentants des peuples autochtones.
TotalEnergies développe ses projets de captage/stockage et de séquestration du CO2 de manière responsable et transparente.

Les projets qui porteront cette compensation sont déjà, et seront, encadrés par des standards environnementaux et sociétaux élevés et TotalEnergies continuera d’agir en transparence au cours des différentes étapes des projets.

Toujours suivant ce même principe de transparence, le projet de CCS Northern Lights en Norvège mentionné dans le rapport a fait l’objet d’une étude d’impact complète, publiée sur le site du gouvernement norvégien.

Le bilan carbone global de la chaîne de valeur du projet a également été évalué (étude ‘Full chain CO2 footprint’) et montre que les volumes de CO2 capturés par le projet seront largement supérieurs aux émissions induites.

La compensation carbone fait donc partie de la stratégie climat de TotalEnergies en tant que levier pour neutraliser les émissions résiduelles, et non pour remplacer les efforts de réduction des émissions de GES qui restent l’axe central de la stratégie.

Les objectifs fixés par TotalEnergies pour ses projets de stockage et de séquestration du carbone sont de 5 MtCO2/an de capacité de stockage pour les projets CCS et de minimum 5MtCO2e/an de capacité de séquestration pour les projets de Nature-based Solutions (NBS) d’ici 2030 (voir ‘Climate roadmap in action’) ; volumes largement inférieurs aux émissions devant être réduites.
Les forêts naturelles présentes sur le projet, actuellement sous forte pression de déforestation, seront intégralement protégées.

Sur l’aspect environnemental, les acacias ont été choisis pour leur capacité de régénération des sols qui leur permettra d’enrichir en matière organique et en azote les sols sableux des plateaux Batéké et de créer une végétation de sous-bois, beaucoup plus diversifiée.

items: Primeramente, es importante comentar que sabemos que el afluente Lerma-Santiago debe de sanearse y restituir, por lo que abogamos para una vigilancia más estricta en conjunto con las autoridades para mejorar la situación de inmediato.
Garantizamos que nuestras fábricas cuentan con todos los permisos y llevan a cabo la totalidad de sus operaciones dentro del marco de la ley.

Con transparencia y contundencia afirmamos que a la fecha nos encontramos operando con estricto apego normativo para la descarga de aguas residuales tratadas en cumplimiento con la NOM-001-SEMARNAT-1996.

Vale encourages EITI to address and implement a specific process related to the possibility of a supporting company eligibility for nomination or re-nomination to EITI Board linked to the company adherence to the EITI Supporting Companies Expectations.

items: TotalEnergies fully supports initiatives for greater transparency and accountability in extractive activities.

Our Company joined the Extractive Industries Transparency Initiative (EITI) as a founding and board member as soon as it was launched in 2003 and supports the important work that has been performed by the EITI in advancing the cause of financial transparency.
TotalEnergies is cooperating in the process set up by the EITI Secretariat intended to build consensus together with the other EITI stakeholders on EITI expectations for supporting companies.
As an EITI board member, TotalEnergies respects and supports this ongoing process, led by the International Secretariat according to EITI governance principles.

TotalEnergies meets all the EITI’s expectations for supporting companies and has published in its Universal Registration Document an annual report of the payments made by its extractive affiliates to governments, project by project, as well as the full list of its consolidated entities, since 2015.

Every worker should feel safe working in our industry, whether they are employed by our suppliers or not.

items: We take all concerns seriously and recognize the importance of stakeholder input to our human rights and sustainable agriculture programs.
We require our direct ingredient suppliers to embrace responsible workplace practices in line with our Human Rights Policy.
We communicate these expectations through our Supplier Guiding Principles (SGP) and verify compliance through onsite audits.

While TCCC does not own farms or manage agricultural production, we require our suppliers to drive sustainable practices at the farm level in line with our Principles for Sustainable Agriculture (PSA), which outline our environmental, social, and economic expectations.
We have paid—and will continue to pay—particular attention to the farming and production of sugar.

We have published 22 country sugar studies transparently detailing our efforts to identify risks to stakeholders involved in sugar production, and we have collaborated with local partners to improve labor conditions across our sugar supply chain, including in Brazil.
We have observed particular improvement in this area through the rapid increase of farms certified by independent third parties, under the mass balance approach.
We invite all interested stakeholders to learn more about our efforts to date in our human rights report.

items: Our company is committed to complying with the applicable laws and regulations of each country in which we operate.
Our success depends on respecting the rights of individuals and groups who interact with us and could potentially be impacted by our business operations and relationships.
BHP believes respecting human rights and contributing to the realisation of human rights are critical to the sustainable operation of our business.
We respect human rights by embedding relevant international standards and frameworks, such as the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, into how we operate (i.e. our systems and processes).

Our Human Rights Policy Statement outlines our approach to respecting and contributing to the realisation of all human rights and in our Policy Statement we commit to respecting the role of human rights defenders and acknowledge the risks they face in upholding civic freedoms.
On January 2022, BHP completed the divestment of its interest in Cerrejón (33.3%), following a global strategy that seeks to transition to higher quality commodities and a more flexible portfolio.
Prior to the divestment process, Cerrejón was an independently managed and operated joint venture, and day-to-day responsibility for the operation lay with Cerrejón management.

We note that Cerrejón has previously provided the Business and Human Rights Resource Centre with the attached letter, dated 20 February 2020, setting out their general approach to responding to attacks on human rights defenders and local leaders.

items: At adidas we are committed to ensuring fair labour practices, fair wages and safe and environmental-friendly working conditions throughout our global supply chain.

With respect to our suppliers, we follow a well-developed and progressive Fair Compensation Strategy, which we have developed in partnership with the Fair Labor Association, a multi-stakeholder US labour rights advocacy group.

Our Fair Compensation Strategy requires that: 1. We do not infringe on the rights of workers, their employers and governments to set fair wages as a minimum; 2. We conduct due diligence and act when business partners are not compliant with the law or our Workplace Standards; and, 3. We facilitate positive wage progression and fair wages in our supply chain.
We seek business partners who progressively raise employee living standards through improved wage systems, benefits, welfare programmes and other services which enhance quality of life.
To complete the benchmark, we reached out to the Ukrainian statistics office to obtain nationwide wage data and, in parallel, conducted wage surveys in each of our partner’ factories.
From the combined data, we created a wage map.
Since our initial benchmarking study, we have continued to track the wage payments for workers employed by these suppliers.

items: H&M Group remains deeply concerned about the situation in Myanmar and is continuously conducting thorough due diligence.

We are aware of increased challenges in relation to fundamental human rights, such as freedom of association, and we have raised this concern with suppliers as well as trade unions, brands and human rights organizations.
In each of the cases raised by the BHRRC, we were informed directly and were able to react immediately to seek a solution.
All issues reported to us have already been resolved, often thanks to close cooperation between local trade unions, our suppliers and the local H&M Group team at the production office in Yangon.
Our team is closely and regularly following up with suppliers to ensure that any violations are identified and appropriately remedied.
In this difficult and complex situation, we cannot stress enough the importance that all stakeholders work closely together to tackle any issues. Partnership and transparency are key.

items: In this regard, Inditex, as a member of ACT (Action, Collaboration, Transformation)1 has shared its deep concern about the developments in Myanmar through a statement published last February 2021 2 which was followed by different concrete actions and processes to help protect and support workers and employers3 until the ACT decision related with the ceasing of the engagement in Myanmar.

1 ACT (Action, Collaboration, Transformation) is a collaboration initiative where Inditex is playing an active role along with IndustriALL Global Union (with whom Inditex has a Global Framework Agreement) and the 19 Global Brands that are part of this initiative.

In addition to this, Inditex has worked with several stakeholders like the initiative SMART Textile & Garments, funded by the European Union and co-funded by private sector partners (brands, retailers, and factories),4 but also with the Ethical Trading Initiative (ETI), including the support to the independent and comprehensive assessment commissioned by this organization concerning the impacts on human rights in the garment sector in Myanmar.

In this sense, Inditex is implementing a responsible policy to follow the above, which implies the respect of the previous commercial commitments assumed, with a clear focus in the following of the UN Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights (UNGPs) and in consequence, having into consideration the impact on workers and employers.

For the case of Yi Cai Garment Factory and SYSMM Apparel Manufacturing, as per the information we have, agreements between union and factories were reached respectively on 30th and 29th August after parties entered into a social dialogue process.
In this sense, we have been informed that the proper remediation has been already implemented through the payment of a compensation to the related workers.
With respect to the factory Zong Hong (Myanmar) Garment Co. Ltd, an investigation has been performed where it was identified a breach on minimum wage in relation to some workers.

Regarding the communication received from BHRRC about some factories located in Myanmar, we would like to share that as per the feedback received from Myanmar Lucky Fortune Garment, it is denied the dismissal of any worker in recent weeks and also it is confirmed from factory side that they did not receive any type of “instructions/message” regarding the firing or not recruiting of workers from any particular region.

Finally, in relation with Kittenish Knitting Co. Ltd, Sinoproud Thein Wa and Myanmar Luxury Group Company, we would like to inform you that after performing an investigation process, we have not encountered any evidence that these factories are part of our supply chain.

items: Inditex has a single global standard in its supply chain.

The Group applies its traceability procedures to follow up on the fulfillment of the standards mentioned above and all the compliance requirements in all the markets where it operates by all the products that the company sells.

items: Tilenga and EACOP projects follow both the Laws and Regulations of Uganda, and Tanzania (for EACOP project), as well as abiding by international best practice including the International Finance Corporation (IFC) Performance Standards, the Equator Principles IV, the UN Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights (UNGP) and the UN Voluntary Principles on Security and Human Rights (VPSHR).

Community Liaison Officers (CLOs) are available to register all project-related grievances including those related to compensation, and to help to resolve them.

There is a four-step procedure in place to handle complaints: registering the complaint, dialogue once the investigation is completed to discuss the proposed solution, the resolution phase if the proposed solution is accepted, and a continued dialogue phase if the proposed solution is not accepted.
In addition to a 30% disturbance allowance, cognizant of the exceptional delays which have occurred, the EACOP project has committed to apply an uplift on top of the compensation calculations.
In Uganda this uplift is 15% after each complete year since the cutoff date.
All complaints are investigated and dealt with regardless of the route used to file the complaint and regardless of who was initially called upon to register the complaint.
Many methods and tools are used to promote dialogue, including village meetings, either with individuals or small groups, site visits and guided tours.

Special attention has been given to ensuring that all members of the community are included, especially women and vulnerable people who might need a different approach to ensure their full involvement.

When there may have been some misinterpretation of the process when the implementation started, particularly to the inventory cut-off date, TotalEnergies remedied the situation as soon as it became aware of this, by initiating a targeted and wide-ranging communication plan (increased dialogue and additional information with the people concerned, as well as radio announcements, and posters and brochures translated into local languages).

Should a PAP not be satisfied with land and assets compensation rates, she or he is able to register a grievance through the Project grievance mechanism, which is in place and respects the efficiency criteria of the UNGPs; EACOP social performance teams are in charge of dealing with these grievances and examine each grievance on a case-by-case basis to ensure that the compensation reflects the full replacement cost.
TotalEnergies and EACOP remain open and would be pleased to discuss any aspect of the project.

Following the allegations formulated in the article, it should be made clear that Uganda has made a choice to exploit its natural resources and that Uganda and Tanzania chose TotalEnergies in light of its operational expertise but also and importantly to ensure that international best practice on social and environmental matters are implemented.

Respect for freedom of association is a key principle of Inditex’s Code of Conduct and the company expressly outlaw’s discrimination against workers’ representatives and union members.

In this sense, Inditex is implementing a responsible policy to follow the above, which implies the respect of the previous commercial commitments assumed, with a clear focus in the following of the UN Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights (UNGPs) and in consequence, having into consideration the impact on workers and employers.

items: At the end of December 2022, Pou Chen Myanmar informed adidas that they had offered the dismissed workers reinstatement, or mutually consented severance for those who did not wish to return to work.

Following multiple rounds of negotiation over the terms of the reinstatement, a final agreement was reached on February 9, 2023.
On signing the agreement, the thirteen workers immediately returned to work.
The local labor rights advocacy group, which had supported the dismissed workers throughout this process, wrote to adidas to confirm that the dispute had been settled.

items: EACOP does not use or tolerate any form of coercion or force, and always engages with PAPs respectfully.

EACOP approach to engagement with these groups includes: • Ongoing consultation and engagement since November 2019,
Negotiation and signing of a Free Prior and Informed Consent (FPIC) Agreement between EACOP and the Akie Community of Napilikunya in July 2022 – the first of its kind in Tanzania,
EACOP has consulted closely with the four of them impacted by the Project - the Akie, Taturu, Barabaig and Maasai to meet all IFC PS 7 substantive requirements in preparation for land access.
EACOP also uses the services of archaeologists and cultural heritage specialists.
A third party Environmental and Social due diligence has been carried out, lasting more than 2 years, against the 8 IFC Performance Standards.
It finds no ‘red flag’ and that EACOP is either compliant, or on track to be compliant in a timely manner commensurate with the advancement of the project, across its activities.
In the event that you become aware of a complaint, we invite you to contact us and refer them to those mechanisms.

EACOP is a public interest project and thus the land acquisition process is ultimately backstopped by a mechanism whereby should PAPs not agree to the terms of the acquisition of land, then the Gov. of Uganda may deposit their entitlements with a Court of Law (and as such this would be ‘compulsory land acquisition process’ very similar to arrangements we have in Europe for Government public interest projects).

There is some confusion in this statement. The 18700 Project Affected Persons are the total number of PAPs (broadly corresponding to households, although they can be other institutions) aggregated across the Tilenga Upstream project, EACOP Uganda and EACOP Tanzania.
Consequently, EACOP has not done anything, other than in these specific areas at the dates mentioned, to prevent PAPs to live on and use their land and indeed has encouraged them to do so.

EACOP is carrying out culturally appropriate grave and shine relocations, compensating cultural heritage sites and providing relocation support in a manner adapted to the customs of each affected person.

items: “We remain fully committed to our pledge and have stopped purchases of Russian origin crude, as well as cargos of refined products exported from Russia.

It is a decision we made with conviction, carefully aligned with government guidance and in compliance with sanctions, which do not exclude purchasing products refined from Russian crude in third countries where this is legally permitted.

“We acknowledge the difficult dilemma that governments face between putting pressure on the Russian government and ensuring stable, secure and affordable energy supplies for consumers in the rest of the world, including Ukraine.”

Through a range of controls, including strict no Russian-origin product contract clauses with suppliers, we seek to avoid any fuels that may contain products refined in Russia (ie where they may have been blended further up the supply chain).
Other refinery-operating companies in third countries may import Russian crude to transform it.

In compliance with sanctions and aligned with government guidance, Shell does not currently exclude purchasing products that may have been refined from Russian crude by third parties in such countries.
We will always comply with applicable sanctions and local laws.

annotations.why_relevant: Expresses a clear change in procurement practice (commitment to stop buying Russian-origin crude) which is a relational signal to suppliers and partners and an operational response to sustainability/political transition risk.

Describes alignment with government guidance and legal compliance while highlighting an exception (third-country refined products), showing regulatory uncertainty and how the company negotiates/frames permissible behaviour.
Acknowledges trade-offs between political pressure and supply security, illuminating the strategic uncertainties companies must manage and the relational balancing with governments and consumers.
Specifies contractual controls ('strict no Russian-origin product contract clauses with suppliers') as a governance mechanism to manage supply-chain ambiguity and to assure compliance among partners.
Notes structural supply-chain complexity (third-country refiners transforming Russian crude), indicating sources of uncertainty that undermine simple origin-based rules.

States the company's practice to follow sanctions and government guidance while permitting purchases of third-party refined products, illustrating how firms operationalize legal/regulatory ambiguity in communications and procurement decisions.
Provides an assurance of compliance with sanctions and local laws, signalling to partners and stakeholders a commitment to legal conformity as a basis for continued commercial relationships.

overall_explanation: The response contains multiple relational-contracting narratives: commitments and procurement changes communicated to suppliers and stakeholders; use of contractual clauses to manage supplier behaviour; alignment with government guidance as a coordination mechanism; acknowledgement of trade-offs and supply-chain complexity that create uncertainty; and legal compliance assurances. These items together address how relational contracts matter in sustainability transitions (RQ1), the types of uncertainty (regulatory, origin/mixing ambiguity, supply security) (RQ2), how the firm manages those uncertainties (procurement bans, contract clauses, alignment with governments) (RQ3), how expectations are communicated and negotiated (explicit statements of policy, alignment with government guidance) (RQ4), and assurances offered to partners (contract clauses and legal compliance statements) (RQ5).

items: Respecting human rights and the environment have long been an important focus of Nestlé’s work - both in our operations and across our supply chains.
This guides our due diligence approach in assessing, addressing, and reporting transparently on actual and potential human rights risks in our business operations and supply chains.

This action plan will help us strengthen our direct suppliers’ capacity to meet our Responsible Sourcing Standard, address risks in our supply chains, and to support indigenous peoples’ and local communities’ projects centered on landscape conservation and restoration.

Importantly, we require our direct suppliers to demonstrate evidence of Free, Prior and Informed Consent (FPIC) from affected local communities when exercising their agricultural and forestry development activities for the raw materials we source from them.

At the end of 2021, more than 90% of the palm oil we sourced was assessed as deforestation-free thanks to tools such as satellite monitoring systems (e.g., Starling), on-the-ground monitoring via partner organizations, and certification.
Moreover, at the end of 2021, 98% of the pulp and paper we sourced was assessed as deforestation-free.

Finally, as part of our Forest Positive Strategy, we continue to focus on landscape initiatives to help protect forests around landscapes where we source key ingredients for our products, and to develop solutions that offer positive benefits for the environment and local communities.

annotations.why_relevant: Positions long-term human rights and environmental focus as central, indicating the role of sustained relationships and commitments in enabling supply chain sustainability transitions (relational contract importance).

Describes a formal due diligence framework for identifying and reporting 'actual and potential' risks—reveals the kinds of uncertainty (actual vs potential) and the procedural way the company deals with them and communicates expectations.

Explains capacity-building for direct suppliers to meet standards and to support community projects—shows relational mechanisms (training/support), reshaping expectations collaboratively, and assurances to enable compliance.
Specifies a concrete supplier requirement (FPIC evidence) — an explicit expectation communicated to suppliers and an assurance mechanism intended to protect communities and ensure compliance.

Details monitoring and verification tools (satellite, on-the-ground partners, certification) used to reduce uncertainty about deforestation and to provide assurances of compliance to stakeholders and partners.
Provides an audited outcome metric (98% assessed deforestation-free), serving as assurance/verification and showing reliance on assessment to manage reputational and supply risks.

Describes landscape initiatives and collaborative solutions under a long-term strategy—illustrates relational contracting through landscape-scale cooperation and shared benefits to foster compliance and transition.

overall_explanation: The response contains multiple sentences illustrating relational-contract elements: long-term commitments, capacity-building for suppliers, explicit supplier requirements (FPIC), monitoring and verification tools, outcome assurances, and landscape-level cooperative initiatives. These passages address the importance of relational contracts (RQ1), types of uncertainty and how they are identified (RQ2), managerial approaches and tools to handle uncertainty (RQ3), how expectations are communicated/negotiated (RQ4), and assurances provided to partners to foster compliance (RQ5). There is no explicit discussion of non-compliance sanctions (RQ6).

items: We are deeply concerned about the allegations of labor violations by one of our manufacturing partners.

While we neither own or operate these facilities, we hold our suppliers to the highest standards and require compliance with all laws and regulations as well as with our Global Supplier Code of Conduct, which specifically prohibits the hiring of underage workers.

annotations.why_relevant: Expresses managerial reaction to alleged violations and signals uncertainty about control and responsibility when suppliers (not owned facilities) are implicated; relevant to types of uncertainty (control, responsibility) and how managers respond to such uncertainty.

States reliance on supplier standards and a Global Supplier Code of Conduct to govern partner behavior, indicating a relational governance approach (implicit expectations beyond ownership), how expectations are communicated (Code), how the firm manages compliance risk with non-owned partners, and the assurances/requirements given to partners.

overall_explanation: The response contains two short sentences that reveal relational governance dynamics: an expressed concern about alleged supplier misconduct (highlighting uncertainty over control/responsibility) and an explicit reliance on and communication of a Global Supplier Code of Conduct to set expectations and require compliance. These items inform research on the role of relational contracts and supplier codes in managing uncertainties, communicating expectations, and providing assurances in supply chain sustainability transitions.

items: Las actividades de la Fundación son monitoreadas (i) por las entidades públicas competentes, a través del Comité Interfederativo ("CIF"); (ii) por el Poder Judicial, en los denominados Ejes Temáticos Prioritarios en curso en el TRF-6, incluyendo la pericia técnica judicial ; (iii) por auditorías externas independientes, todo ello en la forma del convenio que dio lugar a su constitución (TTAC/TAC-Gov), así como por el velo legal del propio Ministerio Público.
Los montos reportados como realizados son debidamente registrados en los estados financieros de la Fundación, siendo PwC responsable de su auditoría contable anual.
Todos los informes anuales de auditoría son remitidos al CIF, al Ministerio Público y publicados en la página web, estando actualmente en elaboración el informe 2022.
Los pagos sólo se realizan después de dicha aprobación judicial, por lo que los montos informados por Renova son debidamente controlados por el Poder Judicial.

Después de la presentación de la declaración de concurso judicial por parte de Samarco, cualquier nuevo financiamiento otorgado a Samarco (por Vale o por terceros) se considera extraconcursal, y su pago no está sujeto a ese proceso.

Las contribuciones eventualmente realizadas después de la solicitud de recuperación judicial de Vale a la Fundação Renova, en cumplimiento del compromiso asumido por ella en el TTAC de hacer el 50% de las eventuales contribuciones anuales no hechas por Samarco, son por naturaleza no concursales y, por lo tanto, su el pago también está sujeto a la competencia establecida en el concurso judicial.
Vale reafirma su compromiso de continuar brindando apoyo para la reparación de los daños causados por la ruptura de la represa de Fundão, en los términos del TTAC y TAC-Governança.
Valoramos la oportunidad de un diálogo continuo con los Business and Human Rights Resource Centre como con otros stakeholders acerca de este importante compromiso.

En cuanto a la alegación de que los valores de compensación “declarados por la Fundación Renova nunca han sido objeto de una auditoría externa seria e independiente”, aclaramos que la Fundación es una entidad privada, sin fines de lucro, basada en la transparencia y el diálogo con la sociedad.

annotations.why_relevant: Describes formal relational governance (TTAC/TAC-Gov) combining public oversight, judicial monitoring and independent audits: shows how relational contracts institutionalize monitoring and cooperative governance in sustainability remediation.
Identifies external financial audit (PwC) as an assurance mechanism to partners and stakeholders, illustrating a concrete accountability device used to foster compliance.
Explains transparent reporting practices (submission to CIF/MP and publication), showing communicative practices to align expectations and provide assurances to stakeholders.
Specifies that payments occur only after judicial approval, highlighting legal/judicial timing uncertainty and an institutional control that mitigates non-compliance risk.
States that new financing after bankruptcy filing is treated as extraconcursal, indicating financial/legal status uncertainty affecting remedies and recovery in transitions.

Records a specific contractual commitment under TTAC (Renova will cover 50% of missed Samarco contributions) and notes its non‑concursal nature and judicial implications, illustrating relational commitments, allocation of obligations and enforcement consequences.
Vale's reaffirmation of ongoing support under TTAC/TAC-Governança signals the role of long-term relational commitments and repeated interaction in sustaining remediation efforts.
Expresses valuing continued dialogue with stakeholders, showing negotiation and communicative processes used to manage expectations and sustain cooperative relations.

Asserts the foundation's basis on transparency and dialogue in response to audit allegations, indicating that trust-building narratives and transparency are used to counter doubts and set expectations.

overall_explanation: The document contains multiple relational contracting narratives: references to TTAC/TAC-Governança as the governing agreements, combined public/judicial oversight and independent audits as assurance mechanisms, judicial approval requirements affecting payment timing, treatment of post-bankruptcy financing as extraconcursal, and explicit commitments (e.g., Renova covering 50% of missed contributions). These items address RQ1 (importance of relational contracts to embed monitoring and long‑term commitments), RQ2 (legal and financial uncertainties such as judicial approval and bankruptcy status), RQ3 (use of audits, public monitoring, and contractual clauses to manage uncertainty), RQ4 (dialogue and transparency to communicate expectations), RQ5 (external audits, judicial controls and public reporting as assurances), and RQ6 (enforcement consequences via judicial approval and non‑concursal treatment).

items: The Renova Foundation, created by the Conduct Adjustment Agreement (TTAC), signed in March 2016 between Samarco, its shareholders, and the Federal, Minas Gerais and Espírito Santo governments and other entities, is a autonomous and independent entity dedicated full-time and exclusively to implementing and managing programs and actions for repairing and compensating damages resulting from Samarco’s Fundão dam failure.
The work of the Renova Foundation is based on transparency and dialogue with society.

The institution's processes are permanently monitored and supervised by independent external auditors, following the guidelines imposed in clauses 198, 200 and 201 of the aforementioned Conduct Adjustment Transaction Term (TTAC).

The Renova Foundation maintains, in its transparency portal (available at https://transparencia- fundacaorenova.hub.arcgis.com/) up-to-date information on expenditure on the various programs under its responsibility, in addition to reports from independent financial audits (available at: https://www.fundacaorenova.org/arquivos-e- relatorios/?search=demonstrativo+financeiro&category=&forum=&data_inicio=&data_fim=).
Furthermore, the TTAC established the Interfederative Committee (IFC), a collegiate system that brings together representatives of public bodies and society and which is led by Ibama.
The IFC works as an external and independent instance of the Renova Foundation, with the function of guiding, accompanying, monitoring and supervising the execution of reparation measures.

Guided by the UNGPs with respect to the important role of operational-level grievance mechanisms, Fundação Renova has two channels for listening and receiving complaints: i. the Ombudsman, dedicated to receiving, registering and investigating denouncements and complaints related to the communities affected by the Fundão dam failure, in Mariana (MG). These manifestations are dealt with by the Renova Foundation Ombudsman area. E-mail: ouvidoria@fundacaorenova.org, telephone: 0800 721 0717 and; ii. A confidential channel aimed at receiving reports on corporate matters, related to non-compliance with the code of conduct, internal rules or current legislation by our employees, contracted or subcontracted third parties.

We trust in Samarco's judicial reorganization process as a way to ensure that Samarco continues to be able to finance Renova, is operationally and financially sustainable, as well as provides a fair return to Samarco's creditors.
BHP Brasil has been and remains fully committed to continue the ongoing support to the reparation and compensation actions.

annotations.why_relevant: Describes an explicit relational-contractual structure (TTAC) involving company, shareholders and multiple governments to create an autonomous institution for long-term remediation — shows how relational contracts institutionalize obligations and shared governance (RQ1), how expectations are codified and communicated (RQ4), and provides assurance mechanisms for cooperation and compliance (RQ5).

Emphasizes transparency and dialogue as relational norms that sustain cooperation over time; indicates how relational contracts rely on trust-building practices to manage transition uncertainty and stakeholder relations (RQ1), and how companies communicate expectations publicly (RQ4); relates to managerial approaches to uncertainty through openness (RQ3).

Specifies the use of independent external audits as an ongoing monitoring mechanism to reduce information and implementation uncertainty; this is an assurance to partners and stakeholders to ensure compliance with agreed terms (RQ3, RQ5).

Points to continuous public reporting (transparency portal, audit reports) as a communication and verification channel that mitigates uncertainty about progress and spending, communicates expectations and provides documentary assurance to stakeholders (RQ3, RQ4, RQ5).

Notes the creation of an Interfederative Committee (IFC) bringing public bodies and society into governance — an institutional relational mechanism that shares oversight and legitimizes the repair process, important for sustaining cooperative commitments in transitions (RQ1) and as an assurance/oversight body (RQ5).

Describes the IFC's role in guiding, monitoring and supervising execution — a practical governance response to reduce implementation uncertainty and to enforce compliance through external supervision; relevant to assurance mechanisms and potential enforcement/sanctioning via oversight (RQ3, RQ5, RQ6).

Describes operational-level grievance mechanisms (ombudsman and confidential compliance channel) used to receive, investigate and handle complaints and non-compliance; addresses how parties can communicate grievances, avoid misunderstandings, and how reports are triaged to remediation/compliance functions — directly relevant to communication, assurances and sanctions handling (RQ3, RQ4, RQ5, RQ6).

Expresses reliance on the judicial reorganization process to secure financing and the long-term sustainability of remediation efforts — highlights financial/legal uncertainty in transitions and a managerial/legal strategy used to provide assurance of continued funding and operational viability (RQ2, RQ3, RQ5).

A declarative commitment by BHP Brasil to ongoing support for reparations, signaling relational commitment to partners and affected communities; exemplifies how firms signal intent to cooperate long-term to reduce relational uncertainty and foster collaboration (RQ1, RQ3).

Frames respect for human rights as central to business success and stakeholder relations, communicating normative expectations and signaling a values-based relational contract that helps align partners and communities during sustainability transitions (RQ1, RQ4).

overall_explanation: The response contains multiple relational-contracting narratives: creation of a multi-party Conduct Adjustment Agreement (TTAC) establishing an autonomous foundation; institutionalized oversight (Fiscal Board, IFC) and independent audits; public transparency portals and grievance channels; explicit commitments to funding and trust in judicial reorganization. These items address why relational contracts matter for sustaining long-term remediation (RQ1), identify key uncertainties (financial, implementation, informational) created by transitions (RQ2), and show managerial responses (governance bodies, audits, public reporting, grievance mechanisms, legal processes) to reduce uncertainty and assure cooperation (RQ3–RQ5). The text also points to mechanisms for identifying non-compliance and processes for investigation (RQ6), though concrete sanctions are less explicitly described.

items: Firstly, Vale clarifies that PTVI operates under high environmental and social standards and the Company prioritizes the safety of people and the environment, acting with respect, care and integrity for our employees, contractors, and community members.
One of its values ‘Life matters most’, Vale places life as more important than material results and goods and incorporates this vision in its business decisions.
After conducting a thorough investigation, the cause of accident was attributed to lack of compliance with work standards.
Changing the tree cutting activity in the mine with the use of equipment to eliminate the risk exposure to employees.
Conducting tiered evaluation on the implementation of Contractor Safety Management System (CSMS).
Increasing supervision at critical activities, both to the employees’ behavior to ensure compliance with work standards and work locations.
Ensuring the competence of inspectors (line supervisors, middle, and managers).
Vale has a commitment to and obsession with safety and emphasizes these ensuring its employees work under a safe, healthy, and secure environment.
Since 2020, Vale has adopted 10 Golden Rules1 which its employees and suppliers must follow, in addition to internal safety programs and campaigns.

Moreover, PTVI encourages the active involvement of employees and partners in creating safe work culture through the Contractor Safety Management System (CSMS) and the Contractor Safety Forum which convenes on a monthly basis.

The company also supports the implementation of the Leadership in the Field program (LIF), which enables leaders to show their leadership and engage directly with the employees to prevent work incidents.

annotations.why_relevant: Declares company commitment to high standards and care for employees, contractors and communities, signalling relational assurances and normative expectations that underpin long-term cooperation and partner trust.
Frames organizational values (‘Life matters most’) that guide business decisions and communicate non-contractual norms and priorities shaping relational contracts and expectations.
Identifies non-compliance with work standards as the root cause, highlighting a typical compliance issue and the investigative response used to resolve uncertainty about incidents.
Describes a concrete risk-substitution response (changing practice/equipment) showing how the company adapts operations to remove hazards and provide assurance to workers and partners.
Mentions tiered evaluations of the Contractor Safety Management System, a monitoring and governance mechanism used to reduce uncertainty and align contractor behaviour with expectations.
States increased supervision to ensure compliance, indicating enforcement/oversight practices to manage behavioural uncertainty and address non-compliance.
Emphasizes ensuring inspector competence, reflecting capacity-building assurances to improve monitoring quality and reduce enforcement uncertainty in supply chain relations.
Reinforces corporate commitment to safety as a relational signal and assurance to partners and stakeholders about priorities and expected behaviour.

Specifies prescriptive rules (10 Golden Rules) that employees and suppliers must follow, communicating clear expectations and forming part of compliance mechanisms and potential grounds for sanctions.
Describes active involvement of employees and partners and a monthly Contractor Safety Forum—an institutionalized forum for communication, negotiation, and relational governance to align practices.

Describes leadership engagement through the LIF program enabling direct leader-employee interaction to prevent incidents—shows managerial strategies to reduce uncertainty and communicate expectations through relational practices.

overall_explanation: The selected sentences contain relational contracting elements: statements of values and commitments, institutionalized forums and programs (CSMS, Contractor Safety Forum, LIF), prescriptive rules for suppliers (10 Golden Rules), monitoring and supervisory measures, capacity-building, and corrective operational changes. These excerpts address how Vale communicates expectations, provides assurances, monitors compliance, responds to non-compliance, and adapts operational practices — relevant to RQs on the role of relational contracts (1), types of uncertainty and managerial responses (3), communication/negotiation of expectations (4), assurances to partners (5), and typical non-compliance issues (6). RQ2 (types of uncertainty) is not explicitly discussed beyond implicit operational and compliance uncertainties covered under RQ3.

items: Mercedes-Benz is currently not intending to source Nickel directly from Indonesia, but is monitoring the worldwide market situation.
In the case of a potential consideration of direct sourcing from Indonesia in the future, the Responsible Sourcing Standards would be taken into consideration accordingly.
With regard to Nickel in Mercedes-Benz’ production material supply chains, the raw material supply chain is currently being assessed in the framework of Mercedes-Benz’ raw material assessments.
Mercedes-Benz has identified 24 critical raw materials during a preliminary risk assessment.
Increasing transparency along the raw material supply chains – especially with regard to certain key components such as battery cells.
To this end, Mercedes- Benz AG contacts the suppliers of the relevant components, for example, and asks them to disclose their structure of subcontractors.
Identification of risk hotspots in these supply chains, e.g. on the basis of the specific risks in the individual mining countries.
Definition and implementation of measures for the risk hotspots and review of whether they are effective over the long term.
The Mercedes-Benz Group publishes the results of these assessments in its Mercedes- Benz Raw Materials Report.

annotations.why_relevant: Direct statement of current sourcing intentions and active market monitoring; identifies market/location uncertainty and shows a monitoring strategy for dealing with supply uncertainty.
Conditional commitment to apply Responsible Sourcing Standards signals how new expectations would be applied and provides an assurance to partners about standards to be enforced.
Describes an institutional assessment framework for raw materials, indicating procedures to reduce uncertainty about supply chain impacts and origins.
Identification of 'critical raw materials' is explicit recognition of supply risk categories introduced by sustainability transitions.
Emphasis on increasing transparency highlights relational-contract mechanisms (information sharing, mutual monitoring) important for sustainability transitions and expectation communication.

Describes active supplier engagement and requests for subcontractor disclosure—an information-sharing practice that establishes expectations, builds trust, and provides assurances to manage supply-chain risks.
Explicit mention of identifying risk hotspots captures the types of geographic and sectoral uncertainty and the company's approach to locating vulnerabilities.

Describes committing to measures and long-term review, indicating relational-contract practices (long-term cooperation, adaptive implementation, and assurance through review) to ensure compliance and effectiveness.
Publishing assessment results is a transparency and accountability mechanism that communicates expectations and provides public assurance to partners and stakeholders.

overall_explanation: The response contains multiple relational-contracting elements relevant to supply-chain sustainability transitions: conditional commitments to standards, active market monitoring, supplier engagement and information requests, identification of critical materials and risk hotspots, implementation and long-term review of measures, and public reporting. These statements address how the company perceives uncertainties (market, geographic, supplier/subcontractor opacity), how it communicates expectations to suppliers, and the assurances and governance practices it plans to use to manage compliance and cooperation (covering RQs 1–5). No explicit sanctions or punitive measures for non-compliance are mentioned (RQ6 not addressed).

items: We do not tolerate any threats, intimidation, harassment or violence against those exercising their Human Rights to freedom of expression to protest peacefully against our business or activities.
TEPU seeks to promote dialogue and exchanges with Human Rights Defenders in the framework of its activities.
Where appropriate as recommended by the UN Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights, TEPU seeks to exert its leverage to influence others to respect these principles.

The Project has a programme for continuous implementation of the Voluntary Principles on Security and Human Rights (VPSHR), notably through the negotiation of a Memorandum of Understanding relating to VPSHR between TEPU and the Government Security Forces;
ongoing VPSHR and human rights training of both Government Security Forces and Private Security Companies deployed in the Project area;

ongoing efforts to ensure that the Project’s grievance mechanisms for community members and workers are effective and able to receive complaints about the conduct of Government Security Forces or Private Security Companies without retaliation.

EACOP staff immediately contacted the individual in question since both TEPU and EACOP have well-developed communications channels with this organization having entered into dialogue with them since mid-2021 with a view to establishing dialogue and creating a pathway for mutual exchange of information.
EACOP and TEPU then put Mr Kayinga Muddu Yisito of COTFONE in touch with the EU Delegation in Uganda who provided support thereafter.

Whenever the Projects are aware that protests are occurring members of staff are immediately mobilised to the site of the protests to verify that protestors are being treated in accordance with the law and that no abuse or violence occurs against them.

Early 2023 TEPU and EACOP reached out to several students who had been part of these and similar protests; through the organisation of breakfast meetings and discussions a meaningful dialogue has been established and has been greatly appreciated by the students.

annotations.why_relevant: Explicit assurance of non-retaliation and communicated expectation toward stakeholders; relevant to how companies signal commitments and assurances to protect rights (RQ4, RQ5).
Describes proactive promotion of dialogue with stakeholders—an element of relational contracting and long-term relationship-building in sustainability transitions (RQ1, RQ4).
States intent to exert leverage on third parties per UNGPs—shows how the firm manages relational uncertainty and provides assurance of intervention (RQ3, RQ5).
References a negotiated Memorandum of Understanding with government security forces—an explicit relational contract mechanism to govern conduct and reduce uncertainty (RQ1, RQ3, RQ5).
Describes training of security actors—a capacity-building assurance to align behaviour with standards and manage operational risks and uncertainties (RQ3, RQ5).
Commits to grievance mechanisms able to receive complaints without retaliation, indicating institutional assurances and pathways for addressing non-compliance (RQ5, RQ6).
Describes immediate outreach and pre-existing communication channels with NGOs—demonstrates relational maintenance and information exchange to reduce misunderstandings (RQ4, RQ1).
Shows facilitation of third-party support (linking an NGO actor to the EU Delegation) as an assurance mechanism and cooperative step in dispute response (RQ5, RQ4).
Describes mobilising staff to verify treatment of protestors—an operational practice to monitor events, reduce ambiguity, and engage authorities to prevent escalation (RQ3, RQ4).
Describes proactive outreach via meetings with students to create dialogue—an example of building trust and new communicative forums to manage stakeholder expectations (RQ4, RQ1).

overall_explanation: The response contains multiple relational contracting elements: explicit commitments and assurances (non-retaliation, grievance mechanisms), negotiated arrangements with security forces (MoU, training), ongoing dialogue and outreach with NGOs and protestors, and use of leverage and third-party facilitation. These items inform how relational contracts reduce uncertainty, communicate expectations, provide assurances for cooperation, and offer mechanisms to address non-compliance (addressing RQs 1, 3, 4, 5, and 6).

items: We continually review salaries and discuss them with union representatives to ensure that our wages are competitive in the market and keep pace with inflation.
Our Supplier Code of Conduct requires companies supplying contractors to comply with all applicable laws, including those concerning labour rights.

Our Supplier Code of Conduct also sets an expectation that our suppliers respect the ILO Core Labour Standards, treat their workers fairly and with respect and respects the rights to lawful freedom of association and collective bargaining.
We expect our suppliers to offer fair and transparent terms and conditions of employment including fair remuneration, working hours and working conditions.

KCC’s supplier agreements are required to contain standard terms and conditions on the requirement for robust health and safety management programmes, upholding respect for human rights, the prevention of child labour, good working conditions and fair salaries.
In addition, since 2020, KCC has successfully participated in the Responsible Minerals Initiative’s programme for its Responsible Minerals Assurance Process.
Supplier due diligence was a core part of this third-party assessment.
Currently, our comparison of employee salaries to local living wages only covers direct employees.

When choosing BSR as our consultant for local living wages, we considered a number of factors in the selection process, including: • Strong external review by international organisations and academia • Application across a range of countries; and • A strong track record of practical implementation to serve as a benchmark for multinational companies.
We are aware that there are other living wage calculation methodologies, suggesting a need for collaboration around harmonisation in calculation methodologies.
In the DRC, the government plays a primary role in evaluating wage levels, making sure that salaries consider both social and economic objectives and are fair compensation for labour.
In the first instance, we would recommend Raid UK address their concerns on the living wage through engagement with the DRC Ministry of Labour.
In addition, we recommend that Raid UK speaks with the Federation des Entreprises du Congo (FEC).
KCC’s Enterprise Development Process works across its procurement programme to support, encourage and engage Congolese-owned businesses.
The DRC Provincial Labour Inspector conducts an annual inspection to ensure all employees, including those employed as contractors, receive the minimum wage and comply with DRC labour law.

annotations.why_relevant: Shows ongoing bilateral communication with unions (relational governance) to manage wage uncertainty, negotiate expectations and provide assurances about pay competitiveness and adjustment mechanisms.
Specifies supplier-facing expectations embedded in codes (soft contractual terms) that signal assurances and standards for contractors, highlighting relational governance beyond formal contracts.
Explicitly communicates normative expectations (ILO standards, freedom of association) to suppliers, indicating how companies articulate new social expectations in supply relationships.
Specifies concrete expectations on employment terms that form the content of relational agreements and provide measurable assurances for supplier compliance.
Shows contractual clauses required in supplier agreements covering H&S, human rights and wages—these are mechanisms for enforcing standards and basis for sanctioning non-compliance.
Participation in third-party assurance schemes shows use of external verification to build trust, reduce informational uncertainty and support sustainability transitions in supply chains.
Identifies supplier due diligence as a central element of third-party assessment—illustrates an approach to managing supplier-related uncertainty through verification.
Acknowledges a scope limitation (excludes contractors), highlighting a source of uncertainty in assessing wage compliance across the supply chain and a managerial boundary that shapes action.

Describes selection criteria for external benchmarking partners, showing how firms build credible external references to negotiate new expectations and support relational commitments during transitions.
Calls for harmonisation and collaboration on methodologies—points to coordination challenges and the role of relational processes for aligning expectations across actors.
Positions government as primary evaluator of wages, indicating institutional uncertainty and the need to coordinate company actions with public regulators in transitions.

Recommends channeling grievances through the labour ministry, indicating how companies redirect stakeholder engagement to public authorities and rely on institutional relationships to resolve disputes.
Points to using business associations (FEC) as multi-stakeholder forums for dialogue—evidence of relational governance mechanisms for negotiating standards and collective action.
Describes active support for local suppliers via procurement processes—an investment in long-term supplier relationships that facilitates sustainability transitions by building capacity and trust.
Identifies external enforcement (labour inspector) as a compliance assurance mechanism, showing how inspections function as sanctions or checks within the relational-contracting environment.

overall_explanation: The extracted sentences contain multiple relational contracting narratives: supplier codes, contractual clauses, engagement with unions and local business forums, third-party assurance and due diligence, limits in scope (contractors), and reliance on government inspections. These items address how expectations are communicated, how uncertainties (methodology, contractor coverage, regulatory roles) are managed, what assurances exist (codes, audits, inspections), and the mechanisms for compliance and enforcement—thereby answering RQs 1–6.

items: Shell made its decision to withdraw from all Russian hydrocarbons with conviction and we have stopped all purchases of Russian crude oil, as well as cargoes of refined products, such as diesel, exported from Russia.
We also exited all our downstream business in Russia, such as services stations.
And we are no longer part of any joint ventures with Gazprom with ongoing operations inside Russia.
Shell has stopped buying Russian LNG on the spot market, but still has some long-term contractual commitments.
This is in full compliance with sanctions, applicable laws and regulations of the countries in which we operate.
We have been clear about this.
There is a dilemma between putting pressure on the Russian government over its atrocities in Ukraine and ensuring stable, secure energy supplies.
It is for governments to decide on the incredibly difficult trade-offs that must be made.

annotations.why_relevant: Expresses a decisive termination of commercial relations signaling the role of long-term relational choices in a sustainability/political transition and how the company acts to manage reputational and operational uncertainty.
Describes concrete exit from downstream operations, showing termination of ongoing relationships and the managerial step of severing ties to address ethical/political concerns.
Notes ending joint ventures, indicating renegotiation or dissolution of relational contracts and strategic responses to transition pressures.

Highlights tension between spot-market purchasing actions and binding long-term contractual commitments, directly pointing to contractual rigidity as a source of uncertainty and the firm's approach of selective disengagement.

Provides an assurance of legal compliance with sanctions and regulations—an explicit guarantee to stakeholders and partners that actions are being taken within legal frameworks to support cooperation and justify decisions.
Claims clarity in communication about the company's stance, indicating an attempt to avoid misunderstandings with stakeholders and partners during the transition.
Frames the core uncertainty as a trade-off between political/ethical pressure and energy security, categorising the type of strategic uncertainty companies face in sustainability transitions.

Demonstrates delegation of difficult trade-offs to governments, indicating a managerial strategy to shift negotiation/governance responsibilities and manage normative uncertainty by appealing to public policy decisions.

overall_explanation: The extracted sentences contain direct relational-contracting content: termination of business relationships and joint ventures, honoring of long-term contracts despite spot-market withdrawal, assurances of legal compliance, claims of clear communication, and framing of trade-offs. items: Respect for freedom of association is a key principle of Inditex’s Code of Conduct and the company expressly outlaws discrimination against workers’ representatives and union members.
At the centre of this work is our Global Framework Agreement with IndustriALL Global Union.

Our local sustainability teams continuously collaborate with IndustriALL Global Union local affiliates in order to promote social dialogue and ensure respect for Freedom of Association and Collective bargaining rights in Inditex’s supply chain.

Regarding this specific case, we received information in late May 2023 about a potential breach related to freedom of association rights at SYSG Garment Company (which is not a direct supplier of Inditex), in Cambodia.

As soon as we received information about this allegation, we followed our usual protocols by initiating a specific due diligence process and contacted the parties involved (namely, SYSG Garment Company and the trade union INTUFE) to clearly understand the circumstances around the case.

During this process we also performed an investigation at the factory, in addition to engaging with the related supplier who is working with SYGS Garment Company, to reinforce our expectations about transparency, collaboration and compliance with Inditex’s requirements on human and labour rights.
We consider that the most effective way to build solid social relations that uphold human and labour rights is to build trust and respectively collaborate.
We have therefore been working on facilitating the social dialogue between the parties involved in the case.
as a result, they have agreed that the dismissed worker will be reinstated and will receive due back payments since the termination date.
A commitment to comply with Cambodian labour law and the factory's internal regulations has also been included as part of the agreement.
We will continue promoting social dialogue and monitoring this case, working together with our direct supplier, the factory SYSG Garment Company and INTUFE.

items: Im Gegensatz zu Ihnen sind wir überzeugt, dass ein Audit durch eine unabhängige Prüfungsgesellschaft wichtige Informationen über die menschenrechtliche Situation im Werk Urumqi liefern kann.
Wir halten an dieser Absicht ausdrücklich fest.
Das Thema Wirtschaft und Menschenrechte ist ein fester Bestandteil unseres Selbstverständnisses und unseres Verhaltenskodex.
Weltweit arbeiten wir mit unseren Partnern an der Einhaltung dieser Werte.
Das Gleiche erwarten wir von unseren Geschäftspartnern vor Ort.

Bei allen Besuchen und Besichtigungen durch leitende Mitarbeiter des Volkswagen Konzerns, des Konzernbetriebsrates und eines Konzernvorstands, zuletzt im Februar 2023, hat es weder Hinweise auf Zwangsarbeit noch andere Menschenrechtsverletzungen im Werk Urumqi gegeben. Andernfalls, und auch das haben wir immer wieder betont, hätten wir unmittelbar und unverzüglich reagiert.
Deswegen werden wir weiter an der Umsetzung des Audits arbeiten. Über Details werden wir Sie und die Öffentlichkeit zur gegebener Zeit unterrichten.
Der Volkswagen Konzern hält sich eng an die Leitprinzipien der Vereinten Nationen für Wirtschaft und Menschenrechte.

Das Werk in Urumqi wird betrieben von der 2012 gegründeten SAIC-Volkswagen (Xinjiang) Automotive Co., Ltd., einer Tochtergesellschaft unserer nicht-kontrollierten Beteiligung SAIC Volkswagen Automotive Co., Ltd.
In den vergangenen Jahren haben wir im Dialog mit Ihnen an unserer Haltung und Bewertung der Situation vor Ort im Werk in Urumqi keinen Zweifel gelassen.

items: The Project is operated by CIMA, a Peruvian conservation NGO who signed a 20-year administration contract (2008-2028) for the CANP with SERNANP, the Peruvian State regulator for Natural Protected Areas.
In March 2021, TotalEnergies Nature Based Solutions (TENBS) entered into an Emission Reduction Purchase Agreement (ERPA) with CIMA whereby TENBS purchases Verified Carbon Units (VCUs) from CIMA.

As project operator, CIMA’s role includes engaging with local communities living in the buffer zone of the National Park, including native Kichwa communities, in line with CIMA’s Human Rights Policy appended in the ERPA.

TENBS is using its influence vis à vis CIMA to continuously improve the transparency of the Project, the level of stakeholders’ engagement and the fair value sharing to reach a positive outcome for indigenous people and local communities involved in the Project, in alignment with the UN Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights and the ERPA contract.

In the specific case of the Cordillera Azul REDD+ project, TENBS decided to invest in a sustainable financial mechanism created and overseen by Peruvian authorities. This mechanism will fund the operational budget of the CANP and other National Protected Areas over the long term: it will secure the financing of the conservation operations for future decades and will have a positive impact on the local communities beyond the generation of carbon credits.

The breakdown of carbon proceeds among stakeholders is project-specific and can be direct and/or indirect and is sometimes determined by the regulatory environment in the country where the project is located.

In addition to TENBS initial and ongoing project monitoring, a dedicated Environment, Social and Governance assessment has been conducted in 2023, to evaluate the implementation of human rights in the daily operations of the Project and identify measures to further strengthen project transparency and governance, stakeholder engagement and value-sharing.
Whilst doing this exercise, due to the legal actions initiated by the Kichwas in Peru against the national authorities, the engagement with potentially affected stakeholders has been limited to date.

the validation and verification body has confirmed that “Community stakeholders from identified community groups supported the assertions of positive impacts from the project on the key focal issues.”

TENBS remains open and attached to multilateral dialogue with CIMA, the SERNANP and external stakeholders to present the sustainable financial mechanism in place and discuss further the co- benefits to impacted local communities, including indigenous people.

items: Vale and PTVI remain open to listening to and to understand the concerns and opinions of our stakeholders.

We take these opportunities seriously and are happy to inform that there is an open dialogue in progress seeking to clarify and address the issues with the communities that raised the socioenvironmental concerns related to PTVI.
On the social front, PTVI ́s interactions with local communities are rooted in dialogue and mutual agreement, ensuring just compensation in line with international guidelines and legal standards.

PTVI appreciates that local communities have established livelihoods, though unlawfully, within certain mining areas and engages in productive dialogue with these individuals/communities and stakeholders in an effort to find a reasonable resolution, despite such activity being considered unlawful.

In conducting land acquisition and/or livelihood compensation, PTVI complies with prevailing laws and the standards and restoration calculations are mutually agreed upon with the community involving the local government.
PTVI also maintains an accessible grievance mechanism for the community to raise complaints or concerns and carries out a formal process for treating demands and complaints from interested parties.
Our Company ́s approach to conflict resolution centers on fostering open dialogue with communities, local authorities, and other interested parties as a means to resolve conflict.
We ensure all security teams undergo training on Human Rights so they may carry out their duties in accordance with the VPSHR and the UNGPs and with due regard for the proportional use of force.
PTVI maintains a positive and constructive relationship with all stakeholders, which includes the military and police.

Following the notice, in October 2023, Vale Base Metals (VBM) established a task force to support PTVI in assessing and strengthening their approach to social, human rights, and environmental impact management in the region.
An investigation was commissioned and VBM is carefully reviewing the findings to align next steps to be implemented by PTVI and will be monitored through the agreed governance procedures.
Since July 2023, the Asuli community has taken control of a self-managed water system initiated and supplied by PTVI.
All activities related to resettlement and compensation follow internationally recognized practice guidelines.
The farmers, for example, mentioned in the letter, who were subjected to involuntary removal, were duly compensated.

items: H&M Group remains deeply concerned about the situation in Myanmar and is continuously conducting thorough due diligence.
We have been monitoring the latest developments very closely and we see increased challenges to conduct our operations according to our standards and requirements.
After careful consideration we have taken the decision to gradually phase out our operations in Myanmar.
We are committed to phase out our business gradually and responsibly which means we will set detailed plans with our suppliers, following ACT Responsible Exit Policy and Checklist.
During this process we will continue to engage with our stakeholders as part of our enhanced due diligence process.
Among others, we will collaborate closely with IndustriAll to act in line with their Framework Principles of a Brand’s Responsible Business Disengagement from Myanmar.
In each of the cases raised by the BHRRC, we were informed directly and were able to react immediately to seek a solution.
All issues reported to us have already been resolved, often thanks to close cooperation between local trade unions, our suppliers and the local H&M Group team at the production office in Yangon.
Our team is closely and regularly following up with suppliers to ensure that any violations are identified and appropriately remedied.
In this difficult and complex situation, we cannot stress enough the importance that all stakeholders work closely together to tackle any issues.
Partnership and transparency are key.

We establish dialogue as early as possible to foster lasting relationships with those communities, and we are mindful of opportunities for community development.
We design and implement grievance procedures and corrective measures, particularly on behalf of vulnerable groups, including indigenous peoples.
Women were informed about grievance mechanism procedure and grievance mailboxes were installed (two in Tutly village and one on site) which are checked continually (see picture below).

items: All of the affected PAPs have been fully compensated and the payments currently stand at 100%.
65 PAPs who were physically displaced by the project were provided with resettlement houses (63 resettlement houses and 2 institutional latrines).
CNOOC also has in place a Grievance Management mechanism, working through the oil and gas committees or Community Liaison Officers.
The project perimeter also does not extend into the lake, and fishing activities have continued alongside CNOOC’s project activities.

From our consultations with the fisherfolk and community leaders, the biggest complaint was that they had not been properly educated and sensitised about the allowable standards before the Fisheries Protection Unit started enforcing the fishing regulations.
Fishermen said they were therefore not aware of the consequences of non- compliance, as well as the enforcement by the Fisheries Protection Unit under the UPDF.
The enforcement by the UPDF Fisheries Protection Unit teams therefore found fisherfolk unprepared to comply with the regulations and the impact on their practices.

MAAIF confirmed that the military enforcement operations on Lake Albert and other water bodies where commercial fishing is conducted in Uganda were being implemented under the Fisheries and Aquaculture Act, 2022 which established a Fisheries Monitoring, Control and Surveillance Unit to oversee and enforce fisheries policies.

From the consultative sessions we held with fisherfolk, they were now more aware of the enforcement of the fishing regulations by the army through the training the awareness sessions received from the NGO as well as government authorities and that this activity is unrelated to oil and gas operations of CNOOC, whose operations are within the same communities.

While community members complained of lack of sensitisation before the disbandment of the settlements, the district leadership on the other hand reported that the impacted villages were engaged and sensitized on the reasons for the disbandment prior to this exercise.

We have consulted with various stakeholders on the subject of UPDF enforcement activities among fisherfolk, i.e representatives from the Ministry of Agriculture, Animal Industry and Fisheries (MAAIF), and consultative session with fisherfolk.
However, no grievances related to human rights violations against the fisherfolk in the Kingfisher area have been received.
For example, we were informed by Kikuube district officials that a military detachment has been present in Kina, one of the villages in the Kingfisher area since 2018.

From our engagements with the district Probation officer, and local area authorities, allegations of sexual harassment could not be confirmed as no grievances have been recorded with them in the Kingfisher area.

items: Aplicamos os mesmos princípios de nutrição, saúde e bem-estar em todos os lugares onde operamos.
Durante a última década, reduzimos em 11% a quantidade total de açúcares adicionados no nosso portfólio de cereais infantis em todo o mundo.
Também continuaremos inovando e reformulando nossos produtos para reduzir ainda mais o nível de açúcares adicionados sem comprometer a qualidade, a segurança e o sabor.
Nosso portfólio segue tais regulamentações locais (ANVISA) e/ou padrões internacionais (OMS), incluindo requisitos de rotulagem e limites de carboidratos - que incluem açúcares.
