items: We agreed to purchase up to 16.88 million Voluntary Carbon Units (MVCUs) for an amount up to 84.7 million USD (MUSD) over 20 years.
Of the amount we disbursed, ~96% were channeled to a trust fund where they remain and generate proceeds, the other ~4%, corresponding to a pre-payment, will also be channeled to the trust fund.
Any future purchase of carbon credits from the CANP by TENBS will continue to feed the trust fund.
TENBS performed reasonable due diligence and investigations, despite limiting conditions at the time (COVID and security conditions within the country).
TENBS and its partner CIMA have worked together to propose improvements related to the management of the CANP and the operational implementation of human rights principles.
To manage grievances, CIMA has put in place a logbook at the checkpoints of the park where anyone can leave comments or complaints, it is accessible to anyone.
The trust fund’s objective is to secure the financing of the CANP in the long-term by protecting it from funding uncertainties that can arise for protected areas.
TENBS has an observer position in its board with no vote.
All future purchases of CANP carbon credits from TENBS are conditional on the implementation of this plan.
In 10/2023, the ERPA between TENBS and CIMA was supplemented to reflect the above improvement prospects which we continue to monitor and assess regularly with CIMA.
TENBS will continue to use its influence in the projects as an important off-taker, especially regarding human rights related aspects.
We would be happy to meet representatives of some of your communities, so as to get direct feedback from them.
If those numbers are inaccurate or don’t fully reflect the reality on the ground, please share facts so that CIMA and TENBS can use them to further investigate.

items: Based on our own direct monitoring we can confirm that all trade unions leaders who had sought election as shop stewards (or assistant shop stewards) were freely elected by the workers at Meng Da.
The elected shop stewards meet weekly and individually with Meng Da’s management team, which provides them with an opportunity to raise any issues of concern.
They are also free, should they so wish, to raise grievances directly with the factory’s Human Resource (HR) Department.
HR has also established a social media app for the factory’s unions, to enable them to post issues to HR that need immediate attention.

Given the number of active trade unions in the factory, adidas has asked Meng Da to seek consensus and endorsement from each union - irrespective of their size - whenever there are any major changes in the workplace, i.e. with respect to workforce planning, overtime arrangements, etc.
This is a practice that has been in place for many years and Meng Da has fully documented all such union endorsements.

adidas has a social compliance team based in Cambodia, which regularly visits our suppliers’ factories and if any Meng Da registered union perceives that the factory is interfering with their trade union activities, the union can raise complaints directly with adidas.
With respect to worker complaints, there are various channels available at Meng Da and these have been communicated to the trade unions, to their members and to all workers.
Those channels include raising a complaint directly with the HR department, or anonymously through the digital grievance app, or the more traditional suggestion boxes.
If workers require support or representation, they can request the unions or shop stewards to act on their behalf, and they frequently do.

items: We expect our suppliers to sign and comply with our Sustainability Commitment which clearly states that these rights are recognized and respected.
To support strengthened industrial relations, we have signed a global framework agreement with IndustriAll and IF Metal.
National Monitoring Committees (NMCs) consisting of H&M Group employees and local trade union representatives implement the agreement in Bangladesh, Cambodia, India, Indonesia and Türkiye.
In 2023, the NMCs covered more than 820,000 workers in our tier 1 supply chain and workers raised 23 issues with these committees, 21 of which were resolved.
Together with 19 other global brands, we’ve partnered with IndustriALL to form ACT (Action, Collaboration, Transformation).
Our joint goal is to achieve living wages by supporting collective bargaining, freedom of association and responsible purchasing practices.
Our public supplier list includes the presence of trade unions and/or democratically elected worker representatives for factories.

We take violations of freedom of association very seriously and we welcome any complaint on possible issues through the channel of our National Monitoring Committees (where present), directly with our teams on the ground or other channels or grievance mechanisms.

This case was raised through the ACT Interim Dispute Resolution Mechanism and we have been actively involved in resolving it through for example fact finding sessions and interviews of impacted workers, mediation role between the two parties (management and trade union) and follow up with factory management on the actions points agreed in meetings with the parties.

In that process we collaborated with IndustriAll, their affiliate trade union BGIWF, factory management and other brands sourcing from Dekko Design and we are thankful to all stakeholders who contributed to that an agreement could be reached in the end.
The last assessment by Better Work Indonesia was conducted in December 2023 and revealed indications of preferential treatment towards one union.
We have made it clear to the supplier that we expect them to uphold Freedom of Association and that discrimination based on union status is unacceptable.
One way to ensure access to remedy when violations occur are effective grievance mechanisms.
We expect all our suppliers to have a grievance mechanism in place so that workers can raise a concern.

We are now working with our strategic suppliers to create tailored roadmaps designed to strengthen social dialogue and grievance mechanisms in the factories in order to improve access to remedy for workers.

items: By way of introduction, we remind that TotalEnergies is the operator of the upstream oil production project Tilenga through its subsidiary, TotalEnergies EP Uganda (TEPU), and it is also the majority shareholder in the East African Crude Oil Pipeline (EACOP).
On the other hand, EACOP Ltd. oversees the construction of the crude oil pipeline.
Responding to your query, we’d like to state that the above press articles claim incidents occurring to human rights defenders and referring to events that are completely unrelated to our activities.
Moreover, neither TEPU and EACOP Ltd have any record of persons, NGOs or Human Rights Defenders raising concerns or grievances in relation to this land.
Further, neither of TEPU or EACOP Ltd work with an organisation called Magnum Security.
Nevertheless, we have sought clarification from the relevant authorities regarding the claims.
We understand that the evictions may have been conducted by a private individual who claimed that the evicted persons were occupying his land unlawfully.

We would like to highlight that the land acquisition process undertaken by TEPU and EACOP Ltd respects local laws and regulations and is compliant with the International Financing Standards (IFS), including IFC Performance Standard 5 on land acquisition and involuntary resettlement.

Finally, in line with TotalEnergies’ approach to respecting human rights of any stakeholders including human rights defenders, TEPU recognizes the importance of protecting human rights defenders and does not accept any threat or attack against those who peacefully defend and promote human rights in connection with its activities.

Also note EACOP Ltd’s commitment to respecting human rights in all its activities and its recognition of the important role of human rights defenders in promoting human rights (https://eacop.com/human-rights- policy/).

items: We wish to clarify that the villages in question, notably Runga and Kiryatete, were initially identified during the planning phase as potential areas to be affected by the project and initial disclosure engagements took place.

However, once project footprint had been fully mapped, it became apparent that the above villages would not be affected by the feeder pipelines as they are situated several kilometers from either Tilenga or EACOP infrastructure.
Consequently, these villages were kept clear during construction and none of the persons mentioned in this article are either Tilenga or EACOP PAPs.
Hence, there was no further engagement on the acquisition of the land in the said villages.

TEPU has also provided some support towards purchase of personal effects which had been requested by the remanded protestors and this has been greatly appreciated.

items: As the European Coffee Federation has outlined in its direct response, it has always been committed to the successful implementation of the EU Deforestation Regulation (EUDR) and has dedicated significant resources to minimize and mitigate the risk of deforestation in the coffee supply chain.

Concerns regarding the implementation timeline of the EUDR were related to the absence of practical tools and guidelines needed to comply with the Regulation, which subsequently had an impact on the ability of all relevant actors to prepare for its implementation.
It was not linked to the industry's willingness to comply.
As Nestlé, we strongly support the objective of the European Commission to protect the world’s forests and restore forests in a sustainable way.
We have consistently advocated for a mix of complementary measures at EU level to address global deforestation in partnership with third countries.
Our work to achieve deforestation-free key supply chains started over a decade ago.
As of the end of 2024, 93.5% of the total volume of our key ingredients – cocoa, coffee, meat, palm oil, pulp and paper, soy and sugar – are assessed as deforestation-free.
Thanks to our longstanding work in avoiding deforestation, we remain confident in our ability to comply with the EUDR.
Since its entry into force, we have made significant investments to close any identified gaps together with our supply chain partners and we continue to work intensely in this area.
We have never called for any delay of the EUDR and have always opposed any calls to re-open the substance of the EUDR for new negotiations.
Nestlé remains supportive of the objectives of the EUDR and its successful implementation.
We will continue to contribute to discussions on the EUDR implementation to support the achievement of this objective.

items: The 40-year duration of the project contracts is needed to support the reality that degraded grasslands, such as those in Northern Tanzania, can take several decades to recover.
Importantly, contracts include exit clauses, allowing villages to review, renegotiate, or withdraw from the agreement where they choose to do so...
Volkswagen ClimatePartner places a strong emphasis on FPIC, ensuring that all participating communities fully understand the project’s terms, benefits, and implications.
The FPIC process begins with an early engagement to introduce the project, explain its broad concepts and its progression from introduction to implementation.
This process includes, initially, the Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) and results in the two project agreements, namely the Carbon Rights Assignment Agreement and the Benefit Sharing Agreement.
Engagement includes women, youth, and village elders, with all agreements requiring final approval from the village assembly before implementation.
Dedicated Maasai team members within SftFTZ lead consultations to ensure cultural sensitivity, inclusivity, and transparency.
An independent data management consultancy tracks all FPIC-related activities to document engagement and ensure full transparency.
The project ensures flexible yet secure governance of grazing activities.
While villages commit to core grazing principles, each village grazing committee designs a specific management plan that is agreed upon by participants.
This plan can be adjusted over time to respond to changing conditions, emergencies, and community needs.
SftFTZ does not acquire or control any land within the project area.
All land titles remain entirely under the ownership of the Maasai villages, in accordance with Tanzanian law.
The project does not involve land sales, leases, encumbrances or transfers to foreign entities.
Initial project payments are used to support project preparation.
The payments are made after the Benefit Sharing Agreements have been signed and after the Rapid Rotational Grazing Plans have been developed.
The methodology requires ex-post soil sampling to determine the actual accumulation of soil carbon over time to avoid over-crediting.
This long-term commitment ensures sustainable land regeneration and stable economic benefits for communities.
Volkswagen ClimatePartner is committed to ongoing engagement with Maasai communities, independent experts, and regulatory bodies.

items: Our commitment to respecting and promoting human rights is critical to our business strategy and a key part of our ambition to enable a just transition to a regenerative food system at scale.

Our Human Rights Framework and Roadmap guides our due diligence approach – assessing, addressing, and reporting transparently on actual and potential human rights risks arising directly or indirectly through our own activities or our business relationships.
We expect all our suppliers to comply with our Nestlé Responsible Sourcing Core Requirements and verify supplier compliance with our requirements on a regular basis.
When we become aware of any concerns, we immediately engage with our suppliers to investigate.

If non-compliances with our Responsible Sourcing Core Requirements are identified, they must be addressed through a time-bound action plan agreed with Nestlé, which will include prevention, mitigation and remediation actions, as appropriate.

We have requested assurance that the ingredients they provide to us meet our Responsible Sourcing Core Requirements—which includes ensuring that it is sourced in accordance with applicable laws and international standards on human rights.

items: The Project maintains a non-judicial Community Grievance Mechanism which follows the international standards (IFC grievance management process, and the United Nations Guiding Principles for Business and Human Rights) and is readily available to households and communities through several channels, and is conducted on fair, informed, and respectful terms (respect for confidentiality to prevent the possible risk of reprisals).
An assistance package to this group was agreed at the end of 2024 and its implementation is ongoing.

This assistance package include a one-off payment including labour cost for land preparation, the opportunity to participate with their land in the agricultural development program implemented by the Project, which includes: (i) support for food production through the provision of improved seeds and technical assistance and (ii) an income generating coconut plantation, (iii) Government committing to provide security of tenure; and (iv) the implementation, in mid-term, of community socio-economic benefits through the formalization of community development agreements with the host communities and the Government.
The Government, the Project and the economic community are looking for alternative means to fulfil the livelihood restoration plan – this work is ongoing and remains constructive.
Since the creation of the Project’s Community Grievance Mechanism, the Project has investigated over 600 compensation-related grievances received and 386 were found to be legitimate.
Of these, 351 have already signed compensation agreements for which payments are being processed.

As far as the Newcomers community members are concerned, given that they will not be asked to leave the land on which they have recently settled, the Project has informed this community that compensation would not be provided.
Upon hearing this, about 50 out of a total of 2,000 of the “newcomers’ community” demonstrated outside of the gate to the DUAT area.
The opening of an investigation has been confirmed by the Attorney General’s Office of Mozambique early March 2025.

The Project continues to actively work on the Resettlement process in order to reach 100% of impacted stakeholders and notes that, from its perspective, the Resettlement process is well underway and ahead of schedule considering the two-year delay on the implementation of the RAP (Resettlement Action Plan) caused by the Force Majeure situation affecting the Project.

items: Our approach to Responsible Sourcing aims to help build the foundations to advance regenerative food systems at scale.

Our work is designed to contribute to the implementation in our supply chain of our commitment towards the UN Guiding Principles on Business and human rights and the OECD Guidelines for Multinational Enterprises on Responsible Business Conduct, thereby helping to transform production practices in a way that will impact positively on people, nature and climate in Nestlé’s sourcing origins.
Our Responsibly Sourced KPI measures the performance of volumes at origin level against our Responsible Sourcing Core Requirements.

Operationally, the criteria to define if a raw material is responsibly sourced is that the material either can be traced to low-risk countries with subnational traceability or that the origin of the material is traceable back to the group of farms and Tier 1 suppliers’ volumes are assessed as compliant with our Responsible Sourcing Core Requirements at production level through one of the following means:
Selected sustainability related certifications
Second or third-party farm selected assessments
On-the-ground programs in which Nestlé directly works with producers (e.g. Nescafé Plan).
We also invite you to peruse our Non-Financial Statement 2024, which has been prepared by Nestlé S.A. in accordance with Articles 964a-c of the Swiss Code of Obligations.
Moreover, in anticipation of the Group’s future obligation to report in accordance with CSRD, the structure, terminology and approach of this report have been prepared with reference to the ESRS.

items: We would like to clarify that, as of today, Stellantis does not have any joint venture or formal collaboration with PT Vale or Huayou Cobalt.

Stellantis is dedicated to maintaining human rights and ethical principles throughout its supply chain, as outlined in our Code of Conduct, Human Rights Policy, and Responsible Purchasing Guidelines.
We align with internationally recognized standards, including the OECD Guidelines for Multinational Enterprises, the UN Declaration of Human Rights, and the UN Convention against Corruption.
We take proactive measures inspired by the International Labour Organization (ILO) rules and the UN Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights.

We require, our suppliers, contractors, and business partners to comply with laws, regulations, and global standards related to environmental impacts, human rights, labor practices, and occupational health and safety and we evaluate the human rights and environmental practices of Tier-1 suppliers through independent third-party audits.

Finally, we have increased our due diligence activities to prepare with upcoming regulations such as the European Union Battery Regulation (EUBR) and the European Union Deforestation Regulation (EUDR) and have prioritized these commitments in our operations to be compliant with the provisions in both regulations.
We would like to call attention to the Stellantis Integrity Helpline, a secure and confidential method for reporting concerns that underpins our commitment.

The Integrity Helpline, which is reachable via the Company’s website, allows employees, contractors, suppliers, dealers and members of the public to report any issues that may concern vehicle safety, emissions or regulatory compliance, or violations to our Code of Conduct.

Stellantis expects suppliers to offer channels for employees and stakeholders to report violations of law or human rights and prohibit retaliation against anyone who makes a good faith report of a violation of policy or law.

items: Firstly, TotalEnergies has not engaged in lobbying activities aimed at delaying and/or weakening South Africa’s carbon tax and climate legislation.
TotalEnergies supports the commitments made by governments to combat global warming as part of the Paris Agreement and publishes its positions on its corporate website1.
TotalEnergies is an active participant in both national and international business and industry associations.

Since 2019, TotalEnergies has been publishing its six principles on its responsible commitment to climate change within industry associations (see p.40 of TotalEnergies’ Sustainability & Climate 2025 Progress Report2).
TotalEnergies Marketing South Africa (Pty) Ltd is a member of the Energy Council of South Africa (ECSA).
Every two years, TotalEnergies’ entities record memberships in industry associations.
1107 industry associations (including the ECSA) and chambers of commerce have been covered for 2023 and for which the list is available on its corporate website4.
Regarding the specific allegations in the report of Just Share, we invite you to contact the ECSA, which is better positioned to provide detailed information concerning its activities.
TotalEnergies’ report regarding the review of industry associations was published in 2024 and can be found on its corporate website3.
TotalEnergies, through its subsidiaries, is actively contributing to the country's energy transition by investing in renewable energy projects and supporting the country's move away from coal.

In South Africa, in accordance with its balanced multi-energy strategy, TotalEnergies through its subsidiaries, maintains a network of over 560 retail sites, distributes Liquified Petroleum Gas nationwide for all domestic energy needs, undertakes exploration projects, and invests in solar and wind projects, including the Prieska solar power plant (86 MW, 27%), which has been supplying more than 70,000 homes with electricity since 2016.

items: We work closely with our direct suppliers and oblige them to comply with our Responsible Sourcing Standards (RSS), to integrate them into their upstream value chains and to monitor compliance with them.
On account of the complexity of the supply chain and the variety of raw materials and other materials in our products, Mercedes-Benz takes a risk-based and strategic approach.
We have developed a due diligence approach in the form of the Mercedes-Benz Human Rights Respect System.
The assessment essentially consists of three steps: 1. Increasing transparency along raw material supply chains – especially with regard to certain key components such as battery cells.
To this end, Mercedes-Benz, for example, contacts the suppliers of the relevant components and asks them to disclose their deeper supply chain.
2. Identification of risk hotspots in these supply chains, e.g. based on the specific risks in the individual mining countries.
3. Defining and implementing measures for the risk hotspots and review their long-term effectiveness.
This enables us to better identify human rights and environmental risks and counteract them in cooperation with our suppliers.

Following our approach of empowerment before withdrawal, we see the strong need for a collaborative effort to mitigate against adverse impacts of nickel mining and processing on human rights and the environment.
That is why we are currently in contact with other OEMs to form alliances for effective measures to protect human rights in the production of nickel in Indonesia in the long term.
We currently don’t source Nickel directly. However, we map our Nickel supply chains in great detail in an ongoing process, as they are dynamic and very complex with many tier stages.

Admits dynamic, multi-tier complexity of nickel supply chains and documents active mapping—identifies temporal and structural uncertainty and a mitigation practice (mapping).

The extracted items are verbatim sentences that support these points.

items: SftFTZ does not acquire or control any land within the project area.
All land titles remain entirely under the ownership of the Maasai villages, in accordance with Tanzanian law.
The project does not involve land sales, leases, encumbrances or transfers to foreign or Tanzanian entities or individuals.
Maasai communities will continue to exercise full rights over their land and maintain their traditional grazing practices.
The 40-year duration of the project contracts is needed to support the reality that degraded grasslands, such as those in Northern Tanzania, can take several decades to recover.
The project agreements can be reviewed to reflect on experience with implementation.
If one side does not meet its core obligations, the other side has the right to terminate the agreement through a defined process.
Volkswagen ClimatePartner places a strong emphasis on FPIC, ensuring that all participating communities fully understand the project’s terms, benefits, and implications.
The FPIC process begins with an early engagement to introduce the project, explain its broad concepts and its progression from introduction to implementation.
This process includes, initially, the Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) and results in the two project agreements, namely the Carbon Rights Assignment Agreement and the Benefit Sharing Agreement.
Engagement includes women, youth, and village elders, with all agreements requiring final approval from the village assembly before implementation.
Dedicated Maasai team members within SftFTZ lead consultations to ensure cultural sensitivity, inclusivity, and transparency.
An independent data management consultancy tracks all FPIC-related activities to document engagement and ensure full transparency.
The project ensures flexible yet secure governance of grazing activities.
While villages commit to core grazing principles, each village grazing committee designs a specific management plan that is agreed upon by participants.
This plan can be adjusted over time to respond to changing conditions, emergencies, and community needs.
The project follows the Tanzanian legal framework on carbon trading, ensuring that revenues are distributed fairly among stakeholders.
Initial project payments are used to support project preparation.
The payments are made after the Benefit Sharing Agreements have been signed and after the Rapid Rotational Grazing Plans have been developed.
The methodology requires ex-post soil sampling to determine the actual accumulation of soil carbon over time to avoid over-crediting.
Volkswagen ClimatePartner is committed to ongoing engagement with Maasai communities, independent experts, and regulatory bodies.

Claims to balance flexibility and security in governance indicate relational efforts to allow adaptive management while protecting agreed norms.

States explicit contractual adaptability over time to cope with changing environmental and social conditions—mechanism to manage dynamic uncertainty.

items: Rest assured that we take these allegations very seriously and have engaged with our direct suppliers as well Solidar Suisse on the general findings.

At Nestlé, we apply stringent due diligence processes throughout our value chain, and our direct suppliers must fully comply with all local laws, international standards, and applicable regulations, and adhere to our Responsible Sourcing Core Requirements.

Since 2021, we have implemented a specific Palm Oil Human Rights Action Plan with our direct suppliers and NGOs to help us better assess, address and publicly report on labor rights risks in our palm oil supply chain.
These national-level plans enable us to identify and understand the most salient human rights risks in specific palm oil production areas, in turn informing any actions that may be needed.

For the last six years, Nestlé has supported palm oil supplier SD Guthrie (formerly Sime Darby) with funding for Suara Kami, an independent grievance mechanism helpline administered and socialized by LRQA.

LRQA staffs Suara Kami with operators who log workers’ grievances in eight languages (Bahasa Indonesian, Bengali, Burmese, English, Hindi, Malay, Nepalese, and Tamil), categorizing the grievances by site, type of grievance, and risk level.
LRQA coordinates anonymized grievance response with a dedicated team at Suara Kami and provides Nestlé with reports on the status of the grievances.
The MoU sets the stage for technical knowledge exchange, capacity-building initiatives, and efforts to improve traceability and smallholder certification readiness.
The MoU also serves as a precursor to the MSPO Impact Alliance — a new multi- stakeholder platform designed to explore and test innovative models that extend the value of certification.

Through collaboration with NGOs, financiers, technology partners, and multinational FMCG companies, the Alliance will enable MSPO to pilot ideas such as green financing for certified producers, digitised traceability solutions, deforestation monitoring tools, and inclusive sourcing incentives for smallholders.
The first steps of the engagement process involve assessing suppliers’ HREDD maturity level, followed by the development of scorecards with recommendations for improvement.
Suppliers are then expected to develop action plans to address identified gaps while being supported with guidance and capacity-building.
Their progress is monitored and annually reported to ensure continuous improvement.
Through the Fund, Nestlé provides targeted co-funding to our direct palm oil suppliers through human rights grants to implement specific projects in Southeast Asia, West Africa, and Latin America.
A cornerstone of the Fund is supplier support through the Earthworm Foundation’s Labour Transformation Programme (LTP).

Each mill and plantation receive a personalized action plan and resources to remedy any potential human rights risks, which the Earthworm Foundation monitor and discuss the progress made during follow-up visits.
Finally, since the publication of the report, representatives from Nestlé HQ and Nestlé Malaysia have visited suppliers in Sabah to get a first-hand understanding of the situation on-ground.

items: We work to inform our decisions with transparent due diligence and supply chain mapping.

Also, when reasonably possible, we engage in vertical integration and direct sourcing of critical raw materials (e.g., lithium, nickel, cobalt) to promote greater visibility, transparency, and alignment with sustainability principles throughout our supply chain.

If material ESG gaps in the supply chain are identified and not adequately addressed through corrective action, we will take appropriate measures, including potential termination of business relationships with our immediate suppliers and/or other measures designed to apply legitimate leverage on the supply chain actors.
This strategy promotes responsible development of upstream industries and fosters long-term partnerships that reflect our shared commitment to sustainability.
